name: Dindshenchas

attributes.attribute: only source for a myth or mythological figure

sources: Gwynn, Edward. The Metrical Dindshenchas. Royal Irish Academy, Todd Lecture Series. Dublin: Hodges, Figgis, and Co, Ltd, 1906–1924. Reprinted Dublin Institute for Advanced Studies, School of Celtic Studies, 1991.
Ó Murchadha, Diarmuid, and Kevin Murray. “Place-Names.” In The Heritage of Ireland, edited by Neil Buttimer, Colin Rynne, and Helen Guerin, 146–155. Cork: The Collins Press, 2000.
Monaghan, Patricia. The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore. Checkmark Books, 2008.
text: Dindshenchas, Dinnshenchas or Dinsheanchas is a text of Irish mythology which is commonly translated as "poetry of place." It refers to the set of ancient Irish texts that describe the myths linked with different locations in the landscape. The exact time of their creation is not known, as they could have been orally transmitted prior to being documented in the Book of Leinster, a 12th-century manuscript, and other medieval documents. Each poem depicting a place describes the myths associated with that particular site, often clarifying the origin of the place's name. The Dindshenchas is the origin of a lot of Irish traditional tales. Due to the poems' indirect approach, sometimes they do not reveal the complete story but instead allude to it. While it serves as an important reference point for the Celtic mythology, it still needs support from other texts. Since the poems were transcribed after the Christian era, it is difficult to determine their accuracy. Nonetheless, in certain cases, it is the only source of information regarding a mythical or mythological figure. See Place-Lore as well.
